text: so our first aim in these negotiations
was to get new protections for countries
like ours which are in the single market
but not in the euro let me take you
through what we've secured we have
permanently protected the pound and our
right to keep it for the first time the
EU has explicitly acknowledged that it
has more than one currency
responsibility for supervising the
financial stability of the UK remains in
the hands of the Bank of England so we
continue to keep our taxpayers and our
savers safe we've ensured that British
taxpayers will never be made to bailout
countries in the euro zone we've ensured
that the UK's economic interests are
protected we've made sure that the euro
zone cannot act as a block to undermine
the integrity of the free trade single
market and we've guaranteed that British
business will never face any
discrimination for being outside the
euro zone
for example our financial services firms
can never be forced to relocate inside
the euro zone if they want to trade in
euros just because they're based in the
UK and not only are these rules set out
in a legally binding agreement we've
also agreed that should the UK or
another non euro member state fear that
the rules are being broken they can
actively they can activate an emergency
safeguard unilaterally to ensure that
these rules are enforced let me be clear
because there has been debate about this
Britain will have the power to pull this
lever on our own our second aim in these
negotiations was to make Europe more
competitive so we create jobs and make
British families more financially secure
we've secured a declaration outlining a
number of commitments in this area for
the first time the European Union will
now say the competitiveness is and I
quote an essential objective of the
Union this is important because it goes
to the very heart of what Europe should
be about it means Europe will complete
the single market in services this will
make it easier for service based
companies like IT firms to trade in
Europe nowhere will this be more of an
opportunity than in the United Kingdom
where thousands of service companies
make up two-thirds of our whole economy
it could add up to 2% to our economy
each year that is a real improvement the
European Union will also complete the
single market in capital this will mean
UK startups will be able to access more
sources of finance for their business
and it will also present new
opportunities for the UK financial
services industry Europe will now also
complete the single market in energy
this will allow more suppliers into the
UK energy market lowering bills and
increasing investment across the
continent that is a real improvement -
in addition we've secured commitments
from Europe to complete trade and
investment agreements with the
fastest-growing and most dynamic
economies around the world
he continues to give details of the deal
that has been you got agreed unanimously
in Brussels tonight so let's get back to
Downing Street and Laura Coons Berg a
big political moment from what you've
heard what is your assessment has he got
enough well Sophie there's no question
in the coming months there is going to
be intensely fierce scrutiny on every
single part of what David Cameron has
only just begun to lay out tonight but
in terms of his big-picture politically
no question what Danny Street will be
most pleased about is the ability as he
said there to end a
something-for-nothing culture for EU
migrants who come here and then have
access to our benefit system that is
politically crucial and something that
many Conservative MPs had been looking
for also there that exemption for the UK
- the fundamental what had been a
fundamental European Union principle
that countries would move closer and
closer together become more and more
alike and of course they are also he
mentioned protections for the City of
London and British business from what's
going on in the eurozone but overall I
think we heard there this central motif
of what he'll say again and again in his
campaign the approach will be we should
be in a Europe where it's live and let
live the Britain can pick the bits of
Europe that it likes and leave aside the
bits of Europe that it does not but
before too long this campaign will move
away from some of the details of those
deal it will move on to how people
politicians and the public feel in their
gut about the European Union
and it's there that he will have a very
intense fight on his hands not least
inside his own cabinet inside his own
political party and a disappointment
from Downing Street tonight that Michael
Gove his close colleague will campaign
to leave the EU but even before he got
to his feet here in London tonight the
campaign to leave was well underway the
ink isn't quite dry on the deal but the
referendum campaign
well it's begun I think the real show
tonight isn't in Brussels but it's here
in Westminster more than a thousand
people standing-room-only packed into a
Westminster Hall tonight getting down to
their business persuading you to leave
the EU turnout tonight is above the fire
limit there are people locked out of the
building because we can't get any more
in it tells you what the public view of
this issue is and the BBC's been told
this man will be joining their ranks he
wears the black and gold of the Lord
Chancellor
he's the justice secretary a senior
figure in government Michael Gove is not
confirming or denying he will campaign
to leave officially still tight-lipped
ruling nothing out number 10 says he's
not yet told the prime minister what
he'll do lovely to see you but there
have been whispers for weeks he'll take
the opposite view even though he and
David Cameron are confidence like their
wives family friends set to be on
opposing sides if it's such a good deal
why are senior figures unconvinced I
think there are some people who have
always been opposed to our membership of
the European Union and they are able to
take that stance if they want to just as
there are some who would stay in the EU
at any price but I believe most of us
want to see a reformed European Union
but could he join Mr Gove as soon as the
cabinet has met probably at 9:00 in the
morning ministers are allowed to go
public if they want to leave the EU so
will Boris Johnson who's discussed it
with Mr Gove this week become an
official
but keeping those different views
politely in the party will take some
doing goals expected support is a coup
for those who want to leave the
campaigns have yet to find a big
conservative hitter I'm feel very very
heartened by it I must say and may well
may many more I'll tell you I'd like to
say up on to the campaign Nigel Faraj
they're all crawling out from under
their rocks at last
to leave the illu it matters to them
which conservative but the campaign's on
both sides may feature some surprising
figures certainly those from different
political parties comrades and friends
what matters will be have and if they
appeal to you
